Award.AbstractNarration:
Representation theory and invariant theory have important applications to, in particular, number theory, physics, combinatorics and geometry. This proposal emphasizes both the analytic and the algebraic theory. The main thrust is an extension of the analytic theory of generalized Whittaker models. These include the Bessel models that have played an important role in the study of automorphic forms and L-functions stemming from attempts at extending the theory of the local Langlands correspondence to groups beyond inner twists of GL(n). The importance of these Whittaker models is that they give a representation theoretic interpretation of the Fourier coefficients of multivariate automorphic forms. The mathematical literature, to date, on Bessel models studies only models for subrepresentations of degenerate principal series. The most general work of this type is the PI?s on previous grants. In this grant he proposes to do a complete analysis of these models for generic principal series. The work will be in part carried out in collaboration with his student Raul Gomez. He expects to have solved the problem for the case of compact stabilizer before the end of the first summer. The general case will be much harder and will be emphasized in the next two years of the grant (after Gomez graduates). The other work will involve more algebraic geometric problems in invariant theory including the structure of the singular set in a semisimple Lie algebra and the Hilbert series of rings of invariants of actions of reductive groups on affine varieties. This work, if successful, will impact applications to geometry and physics.
General Abstract.
Representations and symmetry have played key roles in the recent solutions of some of the most profound problems in mathematics. These include the proof of Fermat?s Last Theorem and proof of The Poincar√© Conjecture in three dimensions. The first example uses representation theory to calculate local factors needed in the proof of a special case of the Langlands Program known as the Taniyama-Shimura conjecture. The second involves the study of the various invariants of the Riemann Curvature tensor and how they evolve under the Ricci Flow. This proposal aims to extend the representation theory involved in these major breakthroughs leading to applications to further developments in number theory (more cases of the Langlands Program) , extensions of applicability of the Ricci flow and related geometry, applications to some amazing recent developments in Conformal Field theory related to exceptional Lie groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant for which I am writing this Outcomes Report is my final individual grant through the NSF. The grant period is 2011-2014 but it is just the last grant of a continuous period 1967-2014. During that period of time the NSF allowed me to raise a family and keep working on my research during the summers. During that period of time I published about 145 papers and 7 books.

 The early papers (1967-1973) were on Riemannian (and pseudo-Riemnnian) geometry leading to The Cahen-Wallach space (a model for general relativity), Do Carmo-Wallach Theory (a classification of minimal immersions of spheres into spheres), Wallach flag manifolds (a classification of even dimensional homogeneous spaces admitting strictly positive curvature including new examples—as of 1972-- of dimensions 6,12 and 24), Aloff-Wallach spaces (an infinite number of homotopy types of simply connected 7 dimensional spaces admitting metrics of positive curvature).

During the period 1970-1995 my research still supported by NSF moved into representation theory.  The major achievements were the paper with Johnson on the spherical principal series, the Wallach set of unitarizable highest weight modules, the classification of unitarizable highest weight modules (the positive energy representations of conformal field theory) with Enright and Howe. This period also included my work with Enright on the realization of the fundamental series and the proof of Zuckerman’s conjecture (the basis for all proofs of unitarity of derived functor modules). In addition, I published my book with Armand Borel on continuous cohomology and representation theory which came out in a second edition in the 1990’s. Other high points of that period involve the Casselman-Wallach theorem which is basic to the part of the Langlands theory related to the so called infinite prime. My version of this theorem was published in my two volume treatise Real Reductive Groups I,II that was also supported in part by the series of grants.

Form 1990-to 2014 the work on representation theory has continued with a proof (and statement) of the Whittaker Plancherel theorem and a strengthening of the Harish-Chandra regularity theorem. But the main thrust of my work in this period involved the interaction between algebraic geometry, representation theory, combinatorics and physics.  This could be considered an outgrowth of my work on invariant differential operators on reductive Lie algebras (published in the Journal of the AMS and partially supported by the NSF Summer Grant) . This paper relates the Springer correspondence (giving a new proof and interpretation) with Harish-Chandra’s regularity theorem. It led to deep questions in algebraic geometry and led me in that direction. High points of this period: Goodman-Wallach books on invariant theory, work with Garsia on combinatorics including the basic structure of quasi-symmetric functions (a proof of the conjecture QSYM is free over SYM) and the introduction of many deep aspects of algebraic geometry into the study of quantum entanglement culminating in my paper in PRL joint with Gilad Gour.
